In early 2001, Musk became involved with the nonprofit Mars Society and discussed funding plans to place a growth-chamber for plants on Mars.[92] In October of the same year, he traveled to Moscow with Jim Cantrell and Adeo Ressi to buy refurbished intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs) that could send the greenhouse payloads into space. He met with the companies NPO Lavochkin and Kosmotras; however, Musk was seen as a novice[93] and the group returned to the United States empty-handed. In February 2002, the group returned to Russia with Mike Griffin (president of In-Q-Tel) to look for three ICBMs. They had another meeting with Kosmotras and were offered one rocket for $8 million, which Musk rejected. He instead decided to start a company that could build affordable rockets.[93] With $100 million of his own money,[94] Musk founded SpaceX in May 2002 and became the company's CEO and Chief Engineer.[95][96]

Musk opposes a "billionaire's tax",[399] and has argued on Twitter with more left-leaning Democratic politicians such as Bernie Sanders,[400][401] Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez,[402] and Elizabeth Warren.[403] He has raised questions about the Black Lives Matter protests, partially based on the fact that the phrase "Hands up, don't shoot" was made up.[404][405] Musk also promoted a baseless theory relating to the attack of Speaker Nancy Pelosi's husband, but Musk deleted his tweet.[406] In May 2022, Musk traveled to Brazil to discuss projects to protect the Amazon rainforest with Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro.[407][408]

Tesla began delivery of an electric sports car, the Roadster, in 2008. With sales of about 2,500 vehicles, it was the first serial production all-electric car to use lithium-ion battery cells.[136] Tesla began delivery of its four-door Model S sedan in 2012.[137] A cross-over, the Model X was launched in 2015.[138] A mass-market sedan, the Model 3, was released in 2017.[139] The Model 3 is the all-time bestselling plug-in electric car worldwide, and in June 2021 it became the first electric car to sell 1 million units globally.[140][141] A fifth vehicle, the Model Y crossover, was launched in 2020.[142] The Cybertruck, an all-electric pickup truck, was unveiled in 2019.[143] Under Musk, Tesla has also constructed multiple lithium-ion battery and electric vehicle factories, named Gigafactories.[144]

Musk was criticized for his public comments and conduct related to the COVID-19 pandemic.[427][428] He spread misinformation about the virus, including promoting a widely discredited paper on the benefits of chloroquine and claiming that COVID-19 death statistics were inflated.[429]


In March 2020, Musk stated, "The coronavirus panic is dumb."[430][431] In an email to Tesla employees, Musk referred to COVID-19 as a "specific form of the common cold" and predicted that confirmed COVID-19 cases would not exceed 0.1% of the U.S. population.[427] On March 19, 2020, Musk predicted that there would be "probably close to zero new cases in [the U.S.] by end of April".[428] *Politico* labeled this statement one of "the most audacious, confident, and spectacularly incorrect prognostications [of 2020]".[432] Musk also claimed falsely that children "are essentially immune" to COVID-19.[433][434]

Musk was partly inspiration for the characterization of Tony Stark in the Marvel film *Iron Man* (2008).[529] Musk also had a cameo appearance in the film's 2010 sequel, *Iron Man 2*.[530] Musk has made cameos and appearances in other films such as *Machete Kills* (2013),[531] *Why Him?* (2016),[532] and *Men in Black: International* (2019).[533] Television series in which he has appeared include *The Simpsons* ("The Musk Who Fell to Earth", 2015),[534] *The Big Bang Theory* ("The Platonic Permutation", 2015),[535] *South Park* ("Members Only", 2016),[536][537] *Young Sheldon* ("A Patch, a Modem, and a Zantac®", 2017),[538] *Rick and Morty* ("One Crew over the Crewcoo's Morty", 2019),[539][540] and *Saturday Night Live* (2021).[541] He contributed interviews to the documentaries *Racing Extinction* (2015) and the Werner Herzog-directed *Lo and Behold* (2016).[542][543]

Main articles: OpenAI and xAI (company)

In December 2015, Musk co-founded OpenAI, a not-for-profit artificial intelligence (AI) research company aiming to develop artificial general intelligence intended to be safe and beneficial to humanity.[280] A particular focus of the company is to democratize artificial superintelligence systems, against governments and corporations.[38] Musk pledged $1 billion of funding to OpenAI.[281] In 2023, Musk tweeted that he had ended up giving a total of $100 million to OpenAI. TechCrunch later reported that, according to its own investigation of public records, "only $15 million" of OpenAI's funding could be definitively traced to Musk. Musk subsequently stated that he had donated about $50 million.[282]

Despite the Boring Company's involvement in building mass transit infrastructure, Musk has criticized public transport and promoted individualized transport (private vehicles).[472][473][474] His comments have been called "elitist" and have sparked widespread criticism from both transportation and urban planning experts, who have pointed out that public transportation in dense urban areas is more economical, more energy efficient, and requires much less space than private cars.[473][475][474]

Tesla acquired SolarCity for over $2 billion in 2016 and merged it with its battery unit to create Tesla Energy. The deal's announcement resulted in a more than 10% drop in Tesla's stock price. ### Accusations of antisemitism[edit]


The Israel government and several media outlets accused Musk of antisemitism due to him spreading George Soros conspiracy theories,[353] although some Israeli officials defended Musk.[354] A tweet of his in November 2023 supported white nationalist ideology[355] and affirmed another antisemitic conspiracy theory that Jews push "hatred against Whites."[356][357] The following day, Musk made a tweet supporting white pride.[358][359] Advertisers distanced themselves from his tweets.[360] Musk wrote that he doesn’t believe that "all Jewish communities" hate white people, but specifically took aim at the Anti-Defamation League.[361]



### Existential threats[edit]

In October 2023, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) sued Musk, alleging that he was refusing to testify in an investigation into whether he violated federal law by purchasing Twitter stock in 2022.[525][526][527] According to the lawsuit, Musk testified twice in 2022 but refused to testify a third time in 2023, claiming the SEC was harassing him.[525][527]

In July 2018, Musk arranged for his employees to build a mini-submarine to assist the rescue of children trapped in a flooded cavern in Thailand.[288] Richard Stanton, leader of the international rescue diving team, urged Musk to facilitate the construction of the vehicle as a back-up, in case flooding worsened.[289] Engineers at SpaceX and the Boring Company built the mini-submarine from a Falcon 9 liquid oxygen transfer tube in eight hours and personally delivered it to Thailand.[290][291] By this time, however, eight of the 12 children, had already been rescued, the rescuers employing full face masks, oxygen, and anesthesia; consequently, Thai authorities declined to use the submarine.[288] In March 2019, Musk was later one of the 187 people who received various honors conferred by the King of Thailand for involvement in the rescue effort.[292]

In April 2019, Musk, through Emo G Records, released a rap track, "RIP Harambe", on SoundCloud.[306] The track, which refers to the killing of Harambe the gorilla and the subsequent Internet sensationalism surrounding the event, was performed by Yung Jake, written by Yung Jake and Caroline Polachek, and produced by BloodPop.[307] The following year, Musk released an EDM track, "Don't Doubt Ur Vibe", featuring his own lyrics and vocals.[308] While *Guardian* critic Alexi Petridis described it as "indistinguishable... from umpteen competent but unthrilling bits of bedroom electronica posted elsewhere on SoundCloud",[309] TechCrunch said it was "not a bad representation of the genre".[308]

Musk expressed interest in buying Twitter as early as 2017,[207] and had questioned the platform's commitment to freedom of speech.[208][209] Additionally, his ex-wife Talulah Riley had urged him to buy Twitter to stop the "woke-ism".[210] In January 2022, Musk started purchasing Twitter shares, reaching a 9.2% stake by April,[211] making him the largest shareholder.[212][e] When this was publicly disclosed, Twitter shares experienced the largest intraday price surge since the company's 2013 IPO.[214] On April 4, Musk agreed to a deal that would appoint him to Twitter's board of directors and prohibit him from acquiring more than 14.9% of the company.[215][216] However, on April 13, Musk made a $43 billion offer to buy Twitter, launching a takeover bid to buy 100% of Twitter's stock at $54.20 per share.[212][217] In response,

In 2017, Musk founded the Boring Company to construct tunnels, and revealed plans for specialized, underground, high-occupancy vehicles that could travel up to 150 miles per hour (240 km/h) and thus circumvent above-ground traffic in major cities.[197][198] Early in 2017, the company began discussions with regulatory bodies and initiated construction of a 30-foot (9.1 m) wide, 50-foot (15 m) long, and 15-foot (4.6 m) deep "test trench" on the premises of SpaceX's offices, as that required no permits.[199] The Los Angeles tunnel, less than two miles (3.2 km) in length, debuted to journalists in 2018. It used Tesla Model Xs and was reported to be a rough ride while traveling at suboptimal speeds.[200]

In 1995, Musk, his brother Kimbal, and Greg Kouri founded Global Link, later renamed to Zip2.[67][68] The company was financed mainly through a financing round of US$200,000, of which 10% was contributed by his father Errol Musk.[69] The company developed an Internet city guide with maps, directions, and yellow pages, and marketed it to newspapers.[70] They worked at a small rented office in Palo Alto,[71] with Musk coding the website every night.[71] Eventually, Zip2 obtained contracts with *The New York Times* and the *Chicago Tribune*.[61] The brothers persuaded the board of directors to abandon a merger with CitySearch;[72] however, Musk's attempts to become CEO were thwarted.[73] Compaq acquired Zip2 for $307 million in cash in February 1999,[74][75] and Musk received $22 million for his 7-percent share.[76]

In 2018, Musk left the OpenAI board to avoid possible future conflicts with his role as CEO of Tesla as the latter company increasingly became involved in AI through Tesla Autopilot.[283] Since then, OpenAI has made significant advances in machine learning, producing neural networks such as GPT-3 (producing human-like text),[284] and DALL-E (generating digital images from natural language descriptions).[285]


On July 12, 2023, Elon Musk launched an artificial intelligence company called xAI, which aims to develop a generative AI program that competes with existing offerings like ChatGPT. The company has reportedly hired engineers from Google and OpenAI.[286] The company, which is incorporated in Nevada, purchased 10,000 graphics processing units. Musk was reportedly obtaining funding from investors in SpaceX and Tesla.[287]

Musk has described climate change as the greatest threat to humanity after AI,[371] and has advocated for a carbon tax.[372] Musk was a critic of President Donald Trump's stance on climate change,[373][374] and resigned from two presidential business advisory councils following Trump's 2017 decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement.[375]

Musk has promoted cryptocurrencies and supports them over traditional government-issued fiat currencies.[466] Given the influence of Musk's tweets in moving cryptocurrency markets,[467] his statements about cryptocurrencies have been viewed as market manipulation by some, such as economist Nouriel Roubini.[468] Musk's social media praising of Bitcoin and Dogecoin was credited for increasing their prices. Consequently, Tesla's 2021 announcement, against the backdrop of Musk's social media behavior, that it bought $1.5 billion worth of Bitcoin, raised questions.[469] Tesla's announcement that it would accept Bitcoin for payment was criticized by environmentalists and investors, due to the environmental impact of cryptocurrency mining. A few months later, in response to the criticism, Musk announced on Twitter that Tesla would no longer accept payments in Bitcoin and would not engage in any Bitcoin transactions until the environmental issues are solved.[470][471]

Soon after the rescue, Vernon Unsworth, a British recreational caver who had been exploring the cave for the previous six years and played a key advisory role in the operation, criticized the submarine on CNN as amounting to nothing more than a public relations effort with no chance of success, maintaining that Musk "had no conception of what the cave passage was like" and "can stick his submarine where it hurts". Musk asserted on Twitter that the device would have worked and referred to Unsworth as a "pedo guy".[293] He deleted the tweets,[293] and apologized,[294] and he deleted his responses to critical tweets from Cher Scarlett, a software engineer, which had caused his followers to harass her.[295] In an email to *BuzzFeed News*, Musk later called Unsworth a "child rapist" and said that he had married a child.[296][297]

In 2018, Musk was sued by the SEC for a tweet claiming that funding had been secured for potentially taking Tesla private.[156][d] The lawsuit characterized the tweet as false, misleading, and damaging to investors, and sought to bar Musk from serving as CEO of publicly traded companies.[156][160][161] Two days later, Musk settled with the SEC, without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations. As a result, Musk and Tesla were fined $20 million each, and Musk was forced to step down for three years as Tesla chairman but was able to remain as CEO.[162] Musk has stated in interviews that he does not regret posting the tweet that triggered the SEC investigation.[163][164] In April 2022, the shareholder who sued Musk over the tweet, along with several Tesla shareholders, said that a federal judge had ruled that the tweet was false, although the ruling in question has not been unsealed.[165] In February 2023, the jury found Musk and Tesla not liable.[166]

In 2015, Musk announced a design competition for students and others to build Hyperloop pods, to operate on a SpaceX-sponsored mile-long track, for a 2015–2017 Hyperloop pod competition. The track was used in January 2017, and Musk also announced that the company had started a tunnel project, with Hawthorne Municipal Airport as its destination.[275] In July 2017, Musk claimed that he had received "verbal government approval" to build a hyperloop from New York City to Washington, D.C., with stops in both Philadelphia and Baltimore.[276] Mention of the projected DC-to-Baltimore leg was removed from the Boring Company website in 2021.[277] The tunnel project to Hawthorne was discontinued in 2022 and is cited to be converted into parking spots for SpaceX workers.[278]


Biographer Ashlee Vance has noted that Musk hoped Hyperloop would "make the public and legislators rethink the high-speed train" proposal current in California at the time and consider more "creative" ideas.[279]



### OpenAI and xAI[edit]

</fragment>
<fragment>
![Musk standing next to bulky medical equipment on a stage](image)Musk discussing a Neuralink device during a live demonstration in 2020
In 2016, Musk co-founded Neuralink, a neurotechnology startup company, with an investment of $100 million.[184][185] Neuralink aims to integrate the human brain with artificial intelligence (AI) by creating devices that are embedded in the brain to facilitate its merging with machines. Such technology could enhance memory or allow the devices to communicate with software.[185][186] The company also hopes to develop devices with which to treat neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease, dementia, and spinal cord injuries.[187]


</fragment>
<fragment>
![Two green vans sporting the SolarCity logo](image)SolarCity solar-panel installation vans in 2009
Musk provided the initial concept and financial capital for SolarCity, which his cousins Lyndon and Peter Rive founded in 2006.[173] By 2013, SolarCity was the second largest provider of solar power systems in the United States.[174] In 2014, Musk promoted the idea of SolarCity building an advanced production facility in Buffalo, New York, triple the size of the largest solar plant in the United States.[175] Construction of the factory started in 2014 and was completed in 2017. It operated as a joint venture with Panasonic until early 2020.[176][177]


</fragment>
<fragment>
![](image)Musk examining F9R Dev1 debris in 2014
Working towards its goal of reusable rockets, in 2015 SpaceX successfully landed the first stage of a Falcon 9 on an inland platform.[104] Later landings were achieved on autonomous spaceport drone ships, an ocean-based recovery platform.[105] In 2018, SpaceX launched the Falcon Heavy; the inaugural mission carried Musk's personal Tesla Roadster as a dummy payload.[106][107] Since 2019,[108] SpaceX has been developing Starship, a fully-reusable, super-heavy-lift launch vehicle intended to replace the Falcon 9 and the Falcon Heavy.[109] In 2020, SpaceX launched its first crewed flight, the Demo-2, becoming the first private company to place astronauts into orbit and dock a crewed spacecraft with the ISS.[110]



#### Starlink[edit]


Main article: Starlink

See also: Starlink in the Russo-Ukrainian War


</fragment>
<fragment>

Tesla's stock market value sank by over $100 billion the next day in reaction to the deal.[222][223] He subsequently tweeted criticism of Twitter executive Vijaya Gadde's policies to his 86 million followers, which led to some of them engaging in sexist and racist harassment against her.[224] Exactly a month after announcing the takeover, Musk stated that the deal was "on hold" following a report that 5% of Twitter's daily active users were spam accounts.[225] Although he initially affirmed his commitment to the acquisition,[226] he sent notification of his termination of the deal in July; Twitter's Board of Directors responded that they were committed to holding him to the transaction.[227] On July 12, 2022, Twitter formally sued Musk in the Chancery Court of Delaware for breaching a legally binding agreement to purchase Twitter.[228] In October 2022, Musk reversed again, offering to purchase Twitter at $54.20 per share.[229] The acquisition was officially completed on October 27.[230]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Immediately after the acquisition, Musk fired several top Twitter executives including CEO Parag Agrawal;[230][231] Musk became the CEO instead.[232] He instituted a $7.99 monthly subscription for a "blue check",[233][234][19] and laid off a significant portion of the company's staff.[235][236] Musk lessened content moderation, including reinstating accounts like the *Bee*,[237][238] and in December, Musk released internal documents relating to Twitter's moderation of Hunter Biden's laptop controversy in the leadup to the 2020 presidential election.[239]


Comments on these internal documents by journalists, Matt Taibbi, Bari Weiss, Michael Shellenberger and others were posted at Twitter as the Twitter Files. The United States House Committee on the Judiciary held hearings on the Twitter Files on March 9, 2023 at which Taibbi and Shellenberger gave testimony. [240]


</fragment>
<fragment>
![Musk shakes hands with NASA Administrator Charles Bolden before a SpaceX Dragon capsule](image)Then-NASA Administrator Charles Bolden congratulating Musk by the SpaceX Dragon following its 2012 mission

</fragment>

<fragment>

In 2019, Musk announced work on a device akin to a sewing machine that could embed threads into a human brain.[184] He is listed as the sole author of an October 2019 paper that details some of Neuralink's research,[188] although Musk's being listed as such rankled the Neuralink team's researchers.[189] At a 2020 live demonstration, Musk described one of their early devices as "a Fitbit in your skull" that could soon cure paralysis, deafness, blindness, and other disabilities. Many neuroscientists and publications criticized these claims,[190][191][192] with *MIT Technology Review* describing them as "highly speculative" and "neuroscience theater".[190] During the demonstration, Musk revealed a pig with a Neuralink implant that tracked neural activity related to smell.[187] In 2022, Neuralink announced that clinical trials would begin by the end of the year.[193]


</fragment>
<fragment>

In March 2020, Musk promised that Tesla would make ventilators for COVID-19 patients if there were a shortage.[441] After figures like New York City mayor Bill de Blasio responded to Musk's offer,[442] Musk offered to donate ventilators which Tesla would build or buy from a third party.[441] However, Musk ended up buying and donating BiPAP and CPAP machines, which are devices that support respirations of someone able to breathe on their own, rather than the much more expensive and sought-after mechanical ventilator machines that are able to breathe for a patient entirely.[443][444]


</fragment>

functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

chat_history.content: Can you find out how many children Jeff Bezos has?

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions": "Look up Jeff Bezos on Wikipedia and find out how many children he has."}

chat_history.content: Jeff Bezos has 4 children: 3 sons and one daughter adopted from China.</s>

functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

chat_history.content: Look up Jeff Bezos on Wikipedia and find out how many children he has.

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions": "Search Wikipedia for the article on Jeff Bezos and skim it to find out how many children he has."}

chat_history.content: Jeff Bezos has 4 children: 3 sons and one daughter adopted from China.</s>

functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

chat_history.content: How many children does Bill Gates have according to the Wikipedia article?

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions": "Find the Wikipedia article for Bill Gates, and tell me how many children he has."}

chat_history.content: Bill Gates has three children.</s>

functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

chat_history.content: Find the Wikipedia article for Bill Gates, and tell me how many children he has.

function.name: search
function.arguments: {"query": "Bill Gates"}
